1062004220449173505.text: Final videos from @dotajames, @JordanFrankfurt and @renepickhardt are now uploaded. Enjoy!

1060927767150243841.text:
Videos of our residents' Lightning apps demos are now online: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLpLH33TRghT2jmuP9YQRo-e8gk969Q2F_ …

Great stuff from @afilini @alexmanusu @andreneves @andrewshvv @talionar @matthewramsden @odedleiba @pierre_rochard @timothyej @treydelbonis @wbobeirne

1060924469441712128.text: Delighted to see Chincode Lightning residency alum @andreneves building tools for the Lightning application developer community:https://medium.com/lightwork/development-tooling-for-invoices-in-lightning-network-applications-cf3d194dc2bb …

1060598950435135488.text: If, like me, you think that Lightning is going to unleash a wave of innovation in Bitcoin application development and you want to know how you can be involved, you should watch every single one of these videos!

1060598885360566272.text: Three years later, Lightning has matured enough to start building those apps. We were lucky enough to host the world experts in Lightning app development at @ChaincodeLabs earlier this month.

1060598770860244992.text: The idea of micropayments and M2M payments was tantalizing, and it seemed possible that Lightning could be the platform that we build micropayment apps on top of.

1060598717693284352.text: I read the Lightning whitepaper in 2015 and it was a big part of what convinced me that I needed to quit my job and work on Bitcoin.https://twitter.com/ChaincodeLabs/status/1060598609979342848 …

1058767343290142726.text: I think that's great advice and wish you'd have taken it.

1058767287434596353.text: I listened to @samouraiwallet on the Stephan Livera podcast to better understand your perspective. You said "it's very, very difficult to have any sort of meaningful conversation of important things like this on Twitter. It would have been a lot better to be handled on email."

1058767189464023040.text: We've had an open channel of communication for the last two weeks. You've had ample opportunity to let me or Steve know if you had any grievance, and could easily have said "thanks but no thanks" to Optech membership.

1058767131351887872.text: And @hrdng ? He just gives his time and expertise away for free, as he has been doing for years, because he's a treasure and one of the most important and generous contributors in Bitcoin.

1058767028163657729.text: The suggestion that we're enriching ourselves by extorting companies is fanciful. James and I are employed by Chaincode and spend some of our time working on Optech because we think it's a valuable community project. Steve gets paid far below his market rate as a contractor.

1058766934043439104.text: We have very generous hosts in Ledger who are providing the venue and lunch. Optech is providing dinners on both nights. No-one makes any profit from this.

1058766882495438849.text: The flipside is that spending two days learning from your peers about technologies like RBF, coin selection, lightning integration, etc, is worth far more than $1000. At least, the other companies sending engineers seem to think so.

1058766836655972353.text: We're holding a two day workshop in Paris for engineers that you were going to attend. The opportunity cost of having two engineers out of office for two days is *far* greater than $1000. Most of our attendees will pay more than $1000 for air fares and hotels alone.

1058766783556055040.text: We got seed money from some very generous funders, and we ask member companies to contribute $5000 to our ongoing costs. For Samourai we offered to drop that to $1000 because you're a small outfit and you probably don't have the cash flow of our larger exchange members.

1058766716560437253.text: Optech has always been entirely transparent about our funding model. See https://bitcoinmagazine.com/articles/chaincode-devs-google-alumni-create-industry-group-help-bitcoin-scale/ … and https://talesfromthecrypt.libsyn.com/tales-from-the-crypt-36-john-newbery ….

1058766637074186241.text: Usually I'd ignore lazy Saturday morning slander from internet trolls, but since you've now accused Optech of criminality and it's not just my name that's associated with Optech, but some of the people I most admire in Bitcoin, I'm going to have to (reluctantly) respond.https://twitter.com/SamouraiWallet/status/1058659055378554880 …

1057272526206877697.text:
Not quite our longest newsletter yet, but it's up there.

As usual, @hrdng cuts through the noise and delivers the signal. Enjoy!https://twitter.com/bitcoinoptech/status/1057271872168120323 …

1055906563926515712.text: And thanks of course to @ChaincodeLabs , @suhasdaftuar and @morcosa for making all of this possible!

1055906507798257665.text: HUGE thanks to @jamesob for putting all of this together! Great job, James!

1055906036232699909.text: Thanks of course to our amazing speakers. @alexbosworth, @chris_stewart_5, @Snyke, @eiaine, @JackMallers, @juscamarena and @LightningK0ala have all been super generous with their time and expertise. Videos of their talks will be online soon.

1055905897552244736.text: Thanks to all our residents for coming and learning with us over the week. It's been a blast and I'm really proud of what you've all built. We're gonna miss you guys!

1055905219869982720.text: Bonus presentation! @Snyke is showing us his docker compose file for spinning up a lightningd testnet. Get a network of bitcoind and lightningd nodes set up in seconds, so you can concentrate on building your app, not wrestling with your infrastructure.

1055902386374479872.text:
Our final ressie is @afilini. He's showing us µBolt - seamless micropayments from the browser.

"Yeah, micropayments are cool (only if you don't have to make them manually)"

How do we solve that? With a browser extension!

1055900271602216961.text:
Now we have @talionar presenting his and @andrewshvv's work on their @Bitlumio wallet.

It's a great-looking wallet and they've taken a lot of feedback from users to make it extremely easy to use.

1055896630300459008.text:
Next up is @andreneves with lightwork - a job board for microtasks, paid for with LN payments.

"I want to introduce people to lightning so it needs to be easy - it needs to be something people are familiar with."

1055882391959560194.text:
Now it's @renepickhardt:

"Lightning network is accessible mainly for nerds!"

He's fixing that by making a custodial Lightning wallet service which is extremely simple, even for non-geeks.

1055867917840146433.text:
Now @wbobeirne is showing Lightning Joule. This is amazing! A browser plugin that allows you to pay lightning invoices on the web.

“This is how interaction with lightning should work. You shouldn’t have to switch contexts. Your browser should speak this language of payments.”

1055866535313588224.text: Next, @odedleiba is demonstrating a pay-per-piece system for distributing software updates for IoT devices, using lightning payments!

1055862232486240256.text:
First up, @matthewramsden is demo'ing his iOS app to integrate with the @SuredBits API.

[paraphrase]: "I could sign up for a starter package for $thousands per month. For me, that's a non-starter package. With lightning I can pay per API call."

1055861366148476929.text: It's showtime at the @ChaincodeLabs Lightning residency! After a week of learning and hacking, our ressies are presenting their projects. Can't wait to see what they've built!

1048028449644793857.text:

Keep buidling your lightning app!

1044017073985409026.text: Last week I was found short in my knowledge and in my judgement. I'm embarrassed and sorry.

1044017039264935936.text: Instead of verifying for myself, I trusted that people smarter and wiser than I am had it covered. I took it for granted that someone else had done the work.

1044017002849939458.text: That comment and the fCheckDuplicateInputs flag don't just smell, they stink. I should have followed my nose. At the very least I should have looked up Bitcoin Core PR #9049. I didn't.

1044016950282727425.text: I spend my days reading the Bitcoin Core codebase. There's no chance I haven't read CheckTransaction(). When I read it, the "...so we skip it in CheckBlock" comment should have jumped out at me.

1044016889117192194.text: I am responsible for the CVE-2018-17144 bug.https://twitter.com/orionwl/status/1043789573984333825 …

1031527716980514816.text: Travel and accommodation stipends are available. Residents should be comfortable building user-facing apps, and *don't* need to be bitcoin/ln experts. So apply today! http://lightningresidency.com/#apply

1007074833035939840.text: These user-merchants are receiving and sending satoshi without the involvement of banks, governments, middlemen or a blockchain. Just private citizens trading with private citizens.

1007074723736510464.text: .@LightningK0ala will probably never retire on the proceeds from http://satoshis.place , but he's already pulled in a few million satoshi. He can now use that to buy t-shirts and stickers (and even cups of coffee if he's in Palo Alto) from other user-merchants.

988187202277597184.text: Any bitcoin people in New Orleans want to hang out this week? My DMs are open!

986247730585591808.text: My man skeeeeees, squashing Bitcoin Core concurrency bugs since 2018.https://twitter.com/BitcoinMerges/status/986243909159411713 …

985340771250339840.text:
If users give up that right and responsibility then Bitcoin as an experiment has failed.

And if that happens, then Bitcoin hasn't failed us, we've failed Bitcoin.

985340701008433152.text: Users are Bitcoin's immune system. Our inoculation against centralisation is users running the code they choose and rejecting any outside attempts to force changes on them.

985340643689017345.text: Devs who have tested, and fixed bugs, and optimized just fast enough to keep up. And users who have made their own free choice to run that code.

985340552261578752.text:
Bitcoin hasn't survived for 9 years because it was perfect to begin with.

Bitcoin has survived because people believe in it and want it to survive. Bitcoin has survived because of the sweat and the guts and the grit of its devs and its users.

985340471319949312.text: Bitcoin's antifragility comes from its web of incentives linking miners, companies, developers and users. At the center of that web are the users.

985340404856950784.text: Users who choose to run full nodes. Users who choose which software to run and which rules to follow. Users who know that progress can only be made by building consensus.

985340306156605440.text:
This isn't repeated often or loudly enough.

Bitcoin is a social experiment, not a piece of software.

Bitcoin is sometimes described as 'antifragile'. Its antifragility doesn't come from lines of code. It comes from its users.https://twitter.com/Excellion/status/985333390877409280 …

956903297369112581.text:
...more people to transact in misery than before. The final result of capacity increases, therefore, is to increase the equilibrium transaction rate, which is to increase the sum total of miserable transactions.

(3/4)

956903234156810247.text:
The Utterly Dismal Theorem of onchain scaling:

Any capacity increase can only relieve misery for a while, for as long as misery is the only check on transactions, the improvement will enable the transaction rate to grow, and will soon enable...

(2/4)

956903156021186560.text:
The Dismal Theorem of onchain scaling:

If the only ultimate check on the growth of transactions is misery, then transactions will grow until it is miserable enough to stop their growth.

(1/4)

955166438783901698.text: Corollary: if you see a service that hasn't adopted segwit, it may be a signal that they're generally careless with other people's money.https://twitter.com/murchandamus/status/955120968120217600 …

954371303619923968.text:
learn; teach; fix; build.

Let this be your credo.

954371173357379584.text: Don't waste your time on those who complain that Bitcoin isn't perfect and don't try to make it better themselves. Don't waste it on those who complain that someone else has spoiled Bitcoin for them.

954371112028266498.text: Therefore: don't waste it on those who snipe from the sidelines without understanding the tech. Don't waste it on those who don't *want* to understand.

954371054939590656.text: Things are moving incredibly fast. There aren't enough hours to keep up with everything that's happening. The only thing more scarce than Bitcoin is your time.

932250279675879429.text:
Really @jgarzik? That's what you learned? How about these lessons:

1. Changes to Bitcoin require consensus from the users and can't be dictated by a closed group.
2. No-one should run untested and unreviewed code from a one-man development team.pic.twitter.com/bkhE1SoaEP

931728074705686528.text: This is so important. Bitcoin Core is a process. We're lucky to have brilliant people involved in the process, but those people are all eventually replaceable. The important thing is the culture of openness and fierce technical review and test.https://twitter.com/suhasdaftuar/status/931706750226583552 …

931662936539631619.text: Can someone with better knowledge of C++ clarify this for me? Jeff claimed on btc1 slack that this would default to false, but I'm not sure that's actually the case.

931554041343217664.text: In case it's not clear: no-one should run btc1 code. It is untested, unreviewed, buggy and can only serve to disrupt and confuse the Bitcoin network.

931554003183431680.text: There are more bugs in the btc1 code. I can't in good conscience reveal what those are, since I have no intention of helping create a disruptive hard fork.

931553950930743297.text: Trying to create a SegWit2x fork at this point, when it's clear that it doesn't have consensus, is simply sowing discord and confusion.

931553920501125122.text: In case it's not clear: SegWit2x only makes sense if it has consensus and can bring the network with it. That's what we were told again and again: 2x is an upgrade and will become the one true chain.

931553851228016640.text: When I pointed this out to Jeff, he immediately created a patch and pushed it out.

931553804109172736.text:
This is a simple bug.

Any reasonably competent coder would have spotted this (not least because a compiler or static analysis could have warned that a member was being accessed before initialization). Any reasonable review process would have caught this.

Sadly btc1 had neither.

931553723532406784.text: I then took a look at the miner activation code. There's another bug there. In the BlockAssembler constructor code, fWitnessSeasoned is being accessed before initialization. The result: no large block can be mined to trigger the fork.

931553682293972992.text: Looking at the code, it appears that Jeff made an off-by-one error. That's not entirely surprising. The VersionBitsState() code is confusing, and the commit where Jeff added the hard fork code had no review: https://github.com/btc1/bitcoin/pull/50 ….

931553622462255104.text: Block 494,784 was announced an discussed as the forking block many times over the last few months. Here https://twitter.com/jgarzik/status/888270313502330880 … and here https://segwit2x.github.io/segwit2x-announce.html … and here https://lists.linuxfoundation.org/pipermail/bitcoin-segwit2x/2017-October/000520.html … for example.

931553577826480128.text: Segwit2x was announced abandoned last week, but there are still some residual nodes in the network. This morning, those nodes froze at block 494,782. That's two blocks before the intended hard fork at 494,784.

931553531471032320.text: I try to assume good intentions in people. Unfortunately, I can no longer do so for @jgarzik. My judgement is that he is acting to disrupt the bitcoin network to advance his own interests.

931375233822584832.text:
Tony, the median feerate for the previous 3 blocks (494722-494724) was 22 sat/vbyte, giving a fee of under 5,000 satoshis for a standard transaction. Your fee is 20x too high.

Are BitPay customers really wasting tens of thousands of dollars on unnecessary fees every day?https://twitter.com/TonyGallippi/status/931370995176345601 …

928642936555876354.text: Phew. I'm glad that madness is behind us. If you've been distracted in the last 6 months, you may have missed the real work happening.

922953406469287936.text: If you care about the ecosystem your company is built on, if you care about your customers' funds, abandon the 2x trainwreck today.

922953296712790017.text: Why create a problem when your company is selling a solution at $500 a coin?pic.twitter.com/GStNGDLBEi

922953184586452992.text: Why does Jeff spend so much time complaining about 'toxicity' and a 'culture of recriminations'?pic.twitter.com/8fO2fKG0s2

922953055519330310.text: Why is service bits discovery disabled so that network disruption on fork day is maximized?https://github.com/btc1/bitcoin/commit/28ebbdb1f4ab632a1500b2c412a157839608fed0 …

896027438488195074.text: I started contributing to Bitcoin Core a few months ago. Here are some of my experiences:https://bitcointechtalk.com/contributing-to-bitcoin-core-a-personal-account-35f3a594340b …

892720462203105281.text: .@BITCOlNCASH it's been 9 hours since the last BCC block and 12 blocks since fork. Is there a problem with difficult readjustment?

888509191458922496.text: ... and far more people than I've mentioned have contributed. If you're interested in the technical details, seehttps://medium.com/@jfnewbery/what-did-bitcoin-core-contributors-ever-do-for-us-39fc2fedb5ef …

888508991550103552.text: Twitter is too terse. These developers have contributed far more than what I've summarized above...

888507659904626688.text: If the answer is 'no', I don't understand what you mean by firing core.

888507574273818624.text: ... and find someone who's prepared to do Wladimir's thankless and never-ending task of merging and preparing releases?

888507476173357064.text: ... delete Jonas's and Nicolas's hardware wallet integration work, so your private keys will always be in your hot wallet...

888507364265119747.text: ... back out Matt's multithreading and scheduling refactors, so your node is mostly limited to running a single process ...

888507260196069380.text: ... erase Alex's fee estimation improvements so you pay too much for your transactions...

888507180793581568.text: ... get rid of Russ's process separation groundwork, so your signing code will be in the same memory space as your network code ...

888507085071282176.text: ... throw out Greg's signature aggregation research so your blocks will contain fewer transactions and take 2-4x longer to validate ...

888506982570876928.text: ... undo Cory's net refactor so your transactions and blocks take longer to propagate across the network ...

888506895941615616.text: ... revert Luke's multiwallet so you can only access a single wallet on your node ...

888506811845922816.text: ... remove Suhas's pruning code, so you need to store tens of GBs of dead data if you want to run a full node ...

888506710649950208.text: ... switch back from Pieter's libsecp256k1 to OpenSSL, so your transaction signing/validation is 5x slower and less secure ...

888506387030003712.text: When you fire core, I presume you're also going to ...

883251213646614529.text: Apologies to Claus Schnorr for the misspelling!

883002399811653634.text: That's why I'm optimistic about bitcoin scaling, and that's why I feel incredibly privileged to contribute in my own small way 9/9

883002234405101570.text: The most intelligent people I've ever met. 8/

883002141073432576.text: The only thing that matters in the long run is that there be incredibly smart people working on this, and there are. 7/

883002011905667072.text: Yes, I want shiny toys like SegWit, Schnoor and sig-agg. But when those things get activated, there'll be the next thing, and the next 6/

883001877591465984.text: No fanfare, no drama, just brilliant people diligently, methodically, conscientiously writing, reviewing and testing quality code 5/

883001740819353601.text: Less than a month before that, sipa's per-txo db PR #10195 went in. 25% faster reindex with lower memory use? Yes please! 4/

883001631125721088.text: Last week, @TheBlueMatt's script caching PR #10192 was merged. BOOM. Block validation is now 30-50% faster. 3/

883001537152286722.text: Every day we learn a little more about how decentralised consensus systems work in the wild. Every day we make bitcoin a little better 2/

883001356168167425.text: Ignore the drama of big-blocks-small-blocks-extension-blocks-2x for a minute. Here's the real story of bitcoin scaling 1/
